Quiet, clean, elegant place in crazy Thamel. Garden of Dreams is just steps away from crazy bustling Thamel. I wouldn't call it spectacular or amazing, but it's really nice and peaceful. In busy Kathmandu it's almost like an oasis of greenery and elegance. You could have a coffee or tea inside and rest after long day for some time. I have to admit, that I was expecting more different flowers, but that was still winter in February, so no surprises. It must be really nice when spring arrives.Entry fee for foreign tourists is 180 NRP (approx. 1,70 EUR) - still acceptable, but do not expect too much.

Clean air and a peaceful repreive in Kathmandu. Definitely go here if you need time out from the crowds and pollution in Kathmandu. Beautiful gardens, a restaurant one end, and bar/cafe on the other end. Lovely place.
Quiet in the city. Take a walk around what used to be opulent living in old Kathmandu. The restaurant has good food but mostly is a rest from the hustle and bustle of the city.
Relaxing Garden. An island of calm in crazy Kathmandu.The restaurant is good.

the garden of aristocrats. This beautiful little garden will enchant you, the architecture is a lovely mix of neo-classic and asian elements and the plants are really exotic and very well assorted. Only regret is the restaurant inside: the food is not bad but way way overpriced. Bring your picninc pack.
Remember when Spring is!. There are no flowers in winter silly. Nice escape from the noise of Thamel though

The heavenly oasis of peace and tranquility in the middle of "madness". Everybody who spends at least few days on the streets of Kathmandu knows the feeling of growing fatigue and frustration…. Huge traffic following “laws of jungle” rather than the road’s code, black clouds of exhaust gases, noise, pollution…. make you dream about an isolated enclave of pure nature where you can recover from this madness….Frankly, it was exactly in Kathmandu when I realized that sometimes dreams can come true. Walking along the wall on the Tridevi Marg Street at the edge of touristic area of Thamel I found a modest sign promising the Garden of Dreams.Intrigued by this unexpected discovery I crossed the small and uninspiring gate to find behind the wall a paradise in the middle of the bustling town. Well, at first moment, may be due to the contrast with busy streets it seemed to me like the biblical Garden of Eden.Short introduction: The garden is a legacy of one man – member of the powerful Rana dynasty ruling the Nepal for more than hundred years (till mid 20th century) – Field Marshal Keshar Shumsher Jung Bahadur Rana. Seasoned diplomat and statesman, but also well educated in literature and art as well as passionate botanist, from his frequent trips to Europe he brought several ideas and inspirations. The most important for future generations turned out to be his idea to create the garden of his dreams in the center of Kathmandu. The second one, was may be not an inspiration but rather an admiration – this time for the Austro-Hungarian Emperor Frantz Joseph. In German the word Emperor is spelled Kaiser, so Keshar promptly changed his name to Kaiser Shumsher. As it turned out both events played an important role in the destiny the Garden of Dreams. At the time of opening in 1920’s the garden was considered as the finest private garden in the world. Just to give you an idea – each of six pavilions built in the garden were dedicated to one of six Nepali seasons. Kaiser Shumsher’s inspiration came from old Sansktit literature and more modern poetry by R. Tagore (winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature).Just for the record – the mentioned six seasons are: Grishma (in Sanskrit Summer), Varsha (Monsoon), Sharad (early autumn), Hemant (late autumn), Sharad (winter) and Vasantha (spring).Well, to keep it short. After the fall of Rana’s dynasty, the garden lost its “virginity”, overgrown by jungle-like vegetation, with polls filled with mud and buildings crumbling. City “devoured” half of this once stunningly beautiful space for urban development…By the end of 20th century the Garden of Dreams resembled rather a “Place of Despair and Desolation”.And here comes (like a Tale from the Grave), Emperor (Kaiser) Franz Joseph or rather his compatriots represented by the Austrian Government and an NGO Eco-Himal. They provided financial help and supervision of reconstruction work. On October 8, 2006 the resurrected Garden of Dreams was re-opened to public. It is a marvelous place to “lick your wounds” immersing in the pristine nature of flower gardens, ponds, water flowers, exotic trees and plants, place to walk along the paths covered by pergolas and trellises, place to sit on the grass and just watch the sky and clouds….. or sip the coffee served in Kaiser Café Bar…..Practical Notes:There are entry fees – for foreigners it is about NPR 160 (probably $2).For about NPR 250 you may have access to Internet (WiFi)Within Garden’s premises operates Kaiser Café Bar and Restaurant (a bit pricey but keep in mind that you are in an Oasis of Peace and Tranquility…. and obviously these kinds of secluded places have to be maintained ….Someone has to pay for that and I think if both Kaisers did it twice, we should follow with our modest contributions to the cause. The bottom line – when in Kathmandu, consider the Garden of Dreams as a place to be (“Must” on you list of attractions).Have a nice afternoon in Garden of DreamsTom

Little Spot of Peace in the craziness of Kathmandu. This was the perfect place to nap in the gardens and read for a couple hours in the afternoon to escape the chaos of Kathmandu and rest between running around to different sites. There is a fee but well worth the price, well maintained and really pretty gardens.

One of the best place to eat in Nepal. hello guys, when you come to Nepal you must go to garden of dreams to eat. its not only good food there. it works as name It is really your Graden of Dreams. Nice garden with alots of beautyful follower,Nice smell.you dont have to anywhere for Day trip.In side Dreams of graden will be your day trip.chers guys

Like a scene from Tomb Raider. The prettiest garden surroundings to see in Kathmandu! Wonderful photo opportunities, if you look for them and the most delicious of meals I think I had while I was in Nepal, washed down with a couple of bottles of suds and then another couple, it was a great seting to unwind and relax and hearing the sound of the fountain in the not so far distance was therapeutic to my ears after all of the honking horns on the dusty streets. I would definately recommend this place for a break from everything, even if it is just for a few hours....I mean suds.

Beautiful. One of the most beautiful and cleanest places in the city. I like how it is seperated from the cars and the street. The garden helps you to relax from the daily hustle and bustle. It would be good if the castle was reconstructed and opened to visitors too. It is full of beautiful works of european inspired architecture, different plants, and flowers. Inside the garden there is also few little cafes. Tickets cost 160 Rupees and it's opened 9am to 10pm. I suggest to visit the garden in spring or summer when there is more flowers and other plants.
Awesome. This garden it,s beautiful I like it, you need go to visit here.
Great place to take a rest and eat in the middle of Kathmandu. Its a peaceful garden and has a restaurant with good food.
Fantastic retreat and restaurant. This was an absolute surpise .. right in the heart fo Thamel, yet it was like a garden in Austria. Great food, and fascinating museum.
Great place for drinks with colleagues. The gardens are beautiful and we had a couple of bottles of good red wine.
Peace and tranquillity. The restaurant ... lovely way to have relaxation in a busy busy city... go for a late lunch !
Garden of Eden. An oasis in the middle of chaotic Kathmandu. It's hard to believe that the city is so close when you enter the garden. Nice for a little break in the day.

Beautiful, peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle. Here, whilst enjoying a cold fanta and a sprite, we had the pleasure of learning the Tiger Moving Game (Nepals national board game) which provided endless hours of fun throughout our trip. The various versions of the instructions also provided entertainment - but you'll have to discover those for yourself!The Garden was delightful. We had a great deal of laughs whilst playing on the swing and watching the fish.
No better place to relax than here!. Want to escape the busy kathmandu life? Come here and experience this beautiful place

Beautiful place. As this is my first visit, I would say the ticket price was get high then that of expected, lods of changes n meintenence needed n water needs to b changed
Guys u take money for entry but u don't maintain the standard. Instead of putting money in ur pocket try to do some better ment for the park

A tranquil haven for lovers. The Garden of Dreams is truly beautiful place - an oasis of serenity in what can be a loud, dusty city. I visited on a fine afternoon and took a late lunch on the terrace. My vegetable pancake was served roasting hot in an oven dish, immersed in baked cheese. Absolutely delicious and piping hot throughout (often, in Nepal, food can be a bit on the cool side). I sat and sipped a coffee, whilst my better half indulged in a complicated but quite gorgeous ice-cream dessert. Our postprandial stroll was most pleasant and I noticed that there are quite a few little nooks and corners tucked-away here and there, most of them occupied by courting couples. It is most unusual to witness public kissing or hand-holding in Nepal, which continues to be conservative and quite prudish about such things. I got quite a few outraged stares when I held my beloved's hand on the street. Yet in the Garden of Dreams such mores do not seem to apply - it is, perhaps, a tolerance zone of some sort.Overall, this is a great place to spend an hour or two - very much recommended.
Not very traditional. Nice, but not very traditional, prices are much higher than in other spots. I would give it a miss.
Nice place to spend a late afternoon, before dinner.... Nice place to spend an afternoon, before you go to dinner.

Greasy Schnitzel. The restaurant seemed upscale, but the food was inconsistent. Cold even though indoors, with loud, distorted music playing. The soup was tasty and grilled veggies okay, but the Schnitzel was very greasy, obviously fried in old oil, and somewhat burnt. Expensive and not work it, including the extra charge just to get into the Garden of Dreams (before you can enter the restaurant). Did not live up to expectations.
Walking distance 4 minute. quite and peaceful environment with historical things

Surprisingly good. Surprisingly good. We had not heard of this place before being there, but were pleasantly struck to find this place nestled around the corner of Narayanhiti place museum. Clean, well-renovated, and dating back to a bit of modern history, this place has very well kept lawns and gardens. Not to mention one of the best decorated and maintained toilets in the entire subcontinent - just cannot forget the terracotta basins!
A beautiful and relaxing garden in Thamel. It's a great project, just amazing what the volunteer workers have created! It's a dream garden in the heart of Thamel.
Excellent garden. A perfect garden near by thamel. when you are inside you feel out of nepal with peaceful enverment. Nice looks and beautyful garden.

Good place to relax. Has a expensive restaurant for Nepal standards but the food was good.. The place has a lot of green and is quiet comparing to what you see outside. There is a fee to go into the garden.

Beautiful architecture. It is conveniently located near Thamel and downtown. The building and the architecture's beautiful, especially the steps. There is also a giant swing in the garden that you can ride on.
Quiet spot. A nice quiet spot in Kathmandu, but the gardens weren't anything special. But maybe it would have looked better in a different season (I visited in December).
a bit of peace. if you have an hour and the weather is nice, take a book and relax on one of the mats provided,
Nice change. It was really a blessing to see such a well maintained garden and breathe some fresh air compared to the pollution filled city of Kathmandu.

Away from the smog. It was smaller than I had thought though beautifully restored.
Too many people!

tranquility in the middle of a crazy city!. We spent a couple of hours here, walking round the gardens and just relaxing. They are really pretty and a great way to chill out from the hectic roads of Kathmandu

Nice but not Special. The garden is loacted on a main road in Thamel. Surprisingly you could not hear the traffic noise given the garden's location.The garden is compact in size and when we went it was extremely busy ,every seat and blade of grass were taken by romancing couples or group's of young girls which were easy on the eye.The Kaiser Cafe which is owned by Dwarika (Kathmandu's leading hotel) is located in the garden which served excellent snacks or meals which is pleasant way to view the garden providing you dont mind spending money on expensive coffee and cakes.

Exquisite settings and a fine restaurant. I took my friends out to dinner at the Garden of Dreams in the grounds of the Kaiser Palace and was amazed to find such a superb setting. In my opinion it would compare with some of the finest restaurants I have been to in other parts of the world. The seafood meal we had was superb and the wine too. It was great value for money - when compared with meals, service and settings of a similar part in any other part of the world.Note: you do have to pay a small entrance fee of less than $2.00 to enter the grounds where the restaurant is.

An oasis of peace. I entered here as I had a few hours to spare and was passing.The garden has been beautifully restored and I spent a couple of pleasant hours wandering round and enjoying the December midday sun. I ate assorted bruchetta and pot of tea, very good cost about 7500 rp. Entrance fee for garden 1600rp
awsome. beautiful place to hangout with friends or specia lones
Amazing gem in Kathmandu!. Most peaceful place ever despite being right in the centre of Kathmandu. Regret I didn't have enough time to chill out on one of the mats provided!
A good respite from hustle and bustle of thamel. lovely drinks, and just a nice place to chill away from the hustle and bustle of thamel.
A nice break. It was a nice break after walking around on the streets for a while.

It was alright. Really not a place to go solo... its a garden where couples cuddle on a bench next to a fountain... or where you go to read a book. Not really a destination to explore on its one, but an oasis to get away from the noise and crowds of kathmandu.

A pleasant way to spend a lazy Sunday. Having decided to check out the garden, I was pleasantly surprised. The garden is well maintained and truly beautiful - worth a walk around. I sat on one of the mats provided and read for an hour after exploring as this was a nice break from the hustle and bustle of city living. The two downsides are it costs to get in (150 NRP I think) and the cafes are expensive. However, as you can take your own food in, this isn't much of a problem. Ideal for relaxing!
Amazing garden. It's a nice garden to read a book. I have a relaxing time in there. It's so beautiful and good time to get sunshine.

A little haven of tranquility in the bustle of Kathmandu. Come in here for a quiet moment or a longer sojourn with a book or for a peaceful snooze. There is a cafe and the gardens are adjacent to the former Royal Palace which is now a national museum and also well worth a visit.
Peace and quiet.. When the traffic gets you down, spend an hour relaxing on the grass here, or watching the fish...guaranteed recharge of the batteries!

Peace amid chaos of Kathmandu. Although you have to pay an entry fee (about 160 R, I think), it was well worth it as this is one of the few palces in Kathmandu where you can find some peace and quiet. Lovely gardens; fountains etc. The surrounding wall is high enough to block out most of the cacophony that is a constant companion in Kathmandu. Close to the Palace museum and a short walk from Thamel centre.

Garden of Dreams. wonderful, quiet oasis in Thamel. Very beautiful setting with great places to sit, read a book of have drink/meal in the restaurant. Sometimes there are music concerts and these are very special too.

Garden Oasis. A quiet retreat just outside of Thamel.
Excellent food and service in the cafe for a very reasonable price, and in an atmosphere that makes you forget about the hectic pace of Thamel just outside.

Delightful, day and night. Go to the Garden of Dreams in the day and you will instantly feel calm and relaxed as you leave the dusty, crazy streets of Kathmandu. At night, we ate in one of the restaurants and both service and food were fantastic. It took a while for the main courses but the majority of us had ordered buffalo steak so completely understandable.
A real Garden of Dreams. A lovely place to have a little walk, read a book, drink or eat something out off the business of Kathmandu

What a lovely little oasis in a city of madness...... Go here for a little bit of piece & quiet! Only 16 npr to get in & beautiful inside. Had coffee & cheesecake in the restaurant but only cos the bar was shut! Gorgeous place :o)
A hidden gem. Beautiful - a super place for coffe and cake during the daytime or a really romantic, high standard meal in the evening. Highly recommended.

Peaceful,clean, friendly service at restaurant. You can take a rest from the hectic situation at Thamel.. The food at the restaurant is good,clean, good service. You can walk in the garden,sit at leisure, read a book and nobody is bothering you
Hidden Gem. Lovely garden to walk sit or lie in - has a restaurant (didnt use) - quite small but lovely - check out the before & after photo's in one of the buildings.

A garden of sweet dreams. right in the middle of the traffic jam, pollution and other street noises, you can find this place, an amazing oasis of silence and green.Visited the place 3 times, twice during the day and once at night.I would suggest to allocate around 4 hours for the daily visit, as you can relax there (they provide mats) where you can read a book, sketch a drawing, listen to music, or just lay and relax.Get yourself an early booking for the restaurant: they serve 'occidental' food at an unreasonable cheap price (alcoholic beverages included)a definite place to visit

Nice quiet garden near Thamel. This garden is a nice place to escape the hustle and bustle of the Thamel area. You can also pay for a wi-fi connection if you want to get some work done outdoors. Expect to see young lovebirds in every nook and cranny of the garden.
just forget where you are. after a day around Thamel streets chilling in the garden is what you need.

Respite from the city's chaos. A serene botanical garden walled off from the chaos of Thamel. Excellent restaurant. Good place to relax on the grass (mat provided by attentive security gaurd) and reflect on your day.

Respite from busy Kathmandu. Visited twice - once during the day and once at night. The garden is a small oasis in the dusty, busy center of Kathmandu. At night, it becomes quite beautiful with the lighting, and the restaurant, although pricey by Nepalese standards, offers great food and service.
Peaceful. Great place to relax in an area that is loud and polluted

A wonderful place to relax right next to Thamel. This Garden is a real pleasure. Located just next to Thamel, it's the perfect hide-away for a few hours, to escape the hustle and buzzle of Thamel. Relaxing lawns (with mats and cushions provided) a very nice Cafe and one o fthe typical giant swings make it a great place to be! Worth tospend the afternoon.
peace. Small peaceful green haven in busy city , thoughtfully provided mats +pillows to allow people to relax and read comfortably on the grass
Peace..... A brilliant oasis in the heart of manic Thamel - bring a book and chill out for a couple of hours

A wonderful surprise. Hidden away behind high brick walls is this delightful garden. It's a little bit of paradise in a crazy, noisy city. Although only a small area it is definitely worth viewing. Some very interesting plants in there too.

A surprising heaven. Despite sitting in the middle of Kathmandu with honking cars and buzzling traffic it is a quiet, clean und fresh place to relax.You can have mats to ly down (free of charge) and relax or sit in one of the two cafes inside the garden.It is advisable to go in the morning - it can get crowded in the afternoons or evenings since it seems to be a popular spot also for Nepalise.There is an entry fee for the day but it is not a "multiple entry fee" so once you have left the garden for the day you have to pay again if you choose to visit again on the same day.
A beautiful garden. An excellent place to chill out for a few hours when the chaos of Thamel becomes too much. Tip, take a picnic as the Kaiser cafe is a really expensive place to eat.
an oasis. you don't hear the noise from the street, very relaxing spot!
Lovely escape from the hectic city. If your hotel has no outside space, come here for a relaxing escape from the city.

A beautiful and surprising gem. Built as the result of money won on a bet between father and son nearly a hundred years ago, the Garden of Dreams is a fragrant, cool oasis in the heart of Kathmandu. With its palms, ponds, statues, urns, arches and pillars it has a symmetry and peace that draws into its fertile soul travellers of the heart and mind. In any location it would be a sanctuary. Surrounded as it is by the urban chaos of Kathmandu it is a well maintained miracle about the size of quarter of a city block. It has about it the magic of oriental delights, secret assignations, intimate spaces where courting couples can find a moment’s privacy in the moonlight. Vistas, steps and buildings through and around which people stroll amongst greenery exotic and local. Fleeting glimpses of times past, of future hopes, ephemeral as dreams, as cool as the breeze that flows through pillars, soothing a green heart, fanning the fire of an enigmatic passion.This quote from the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayam is on a brass plate inside the entrance.Ah, Moon of my Delight, who know’st no wane,The Moon of Heaven rising once again:How oft hereafter rising shall she lookThrough this same Garden after me – in vain!

A breath of fresh air. I am originally from ktm... and living overseas for a couple of year now... and when I visited this garden on my trip back home, I must say I was impressed. Like the other reviews say, it definitely does not feel as if it is in Nepal, but some other developed countries. And it is true, this is not real Nepal, so visit to this garden would mainly be for the amazing ambience, the food..coffee...relax.. and to get a bit of me time! And I read about people complaining about the fees.. which is hardly $2 USD... let me just clarify, that if these fees were not implemented ( which is still a very high amount for most of the poor nepalese people), this place too will be rigged by the people who have no awareness about keeping a place neat and tidy. So be thankful and there is a small fees!

Welcome escape. What a welcome escape from the sometimes chaotic streets of Kathmandu. We stumbled into the Garden of Dreams mid afternoon, sat in the restaurant and enjoyed a few drinks and momos before walking around the garden. What a great way to spend a lazy afternoon!

Haven amongst the chaos of Kathmandu. We visited the Garden of Dreams on our last day in Kathmandu, while waiting for the flight back to Dubai. The gardens are nice, but by no means would I rank them 1 (currently) out of all the things there are to do in Kathmandu. The gardens are within walking distance from Thamel and a good place to visit to get away from the chaos of Kathmandu. We enjoyed a late morning at the gardens, including a nice coffee at one of the restaurants there. Certainly it is worth the Rs 160 (just over USD 1) per person entry fee, though I do not believe it is worth the number 1 ranking of things to do in Kathmandu. Our favorite site of the whole trip was Pashupatinath Temple – that was fascinating, and, more importantly, culturally enriching.
Excellent. In India also, we dont have such restaurants. Amazing restaurant and i was surprised to see such an ambiance and food in NepalDefinitely recommended to all who visit Nepal

Oasis of peace amidst the crowds and chaos. Kathmandu has developed into a teeming and congested capital city, with what seems to be too many people, too narrow roads. The Garden of Dreams in the centr of Kathmandu comes as a complete surprise to almost everyone that stumbles across it. As it is completely walled, it is impossible to view from the road, and most travellers would pass by it continually, without ever knowing it exists, unless tipped off by someone else. It is located next door to the Ministry of Education and opposite the Royal Palace Museum, on the corner of the Kantipath main road, and Tridevi Sadak (the road leacing into Thamel Chowk and the Thamel tourist area).The garden is open from 9am until 10pm. There is an entry fee of Rs160 for foreign visitors, and once inside, there is the Basanta coffee bar and the Kaiser Cafe (owned and operated by the fabulous Dwarika's Hotel)The development of the Kaiser Mahal Garden of Dreams was started in the 1920s by Field Marshall Kaiser Shumsher Jung Bahadur Rana (1892 - 1964), who was captivated by the classically designed palace gardens of British royalty, and wanted to do something similar in Kathmandu. Surprisingly the garden lay derelict for a long time until being recently refurbished, and is now an absolute delight with a variety of pavilions, gardens, lilypond pools, arches, marble cupolas, and nooks and crannies where people can stroll, stretch out, chat and relax in peace, quiet and relative privacy. Garden attendants will lay double mattress squabs and pillows out on the grass for visitors to stretch out on during the day, and at night the gardens are transformed with atmospheric lighting, gas flames in the reflection pools, etc. It really is something special and a breath of fresh air in a busy Kathmandu day. It is easily one of the most romantic spots in Kathmandu and is a regular hangout for courting couples and students needing a quiet place to study or read.
A Must Do in Kathmandu. The garden was beautiful--spend the day. The restaurant located within the garden was very good or take a croissant from breakfast.

Amaaaaaazing. The most incredible garden and restaurant situated smack bang in the middle of Kathmandu central, so happy to have stumbled across it by accident when hitting the shops in Tamil. Worth stopping in at, having a few drinks and catching your breath.

An oasis of peace and green in a dirty poluted city. My wife worked in Nepal, Kathmandu for a year and this was one of the best places for her to relax. Kathmandu is an average 'third' world capital, crowded, noisy and poluted and in such an environment the Garden of Dreams, a former palace garden where you can eat, drink or just relax, is an Oasis!. If the food was a better i might have even given it all five stars. In that year i visitted my wife several times and even though she had a nice house i hated Kathmandu... Still the garden of dreams was one of those places that made it all better. If you are in Kathmandu and you want to get away from it all... go to the Garden of Dreams!.

Refreshing place to go to. If you want to find a place where you can relax within Kathmandu then i recommend this place. Once you enter you would not expect that it is existing within the city. The garden is not that big but you can find several bench to relax with. You can even borrow a mat from the reception (free of charge) and take a nap or just to chill out within the area. They have a nice bar and restaurant but i find the prices a bit high.

Garden of Dreams - Heaven. For most westerners visiting chaotic and dirty Kathmandu, this is a haven to remind you of what can be done - with money and care. Recommend the Kaiser Cafe in the garden also. This was the highlight of trip to Nepal.Interesting to compare this to the Palace Museum where the gardens are unkempt and deteriorating.

Place you feel you're not in Kathmandu. Honestly speaking, there is not much to see... It is simply a garden... Pretty relaxing after a busy day... But, you will feel that you re not in Nepal as it seems you're in a garden in Europe instead. It cost Rs 160. Hard to say whether it worths!?

Secret place away from bustling Thamel. It was my third trip to Nepal and, thanks to TA I finally landed in this outstanding place. Clean, quiet, green. You can just take a (free) matress, lie down and rest absorbing extraordinary atmosphere. There are two cafes on-site, slightly overpriced and the waiters are mannered. Two clean bathrooms as an added value :) In my opinion a must-see place, especially after your trekking activity. Kathmandu's Premier League!.

A refuge from the manic world of Kathmandu.. A wonderfully kept secret that even our guide and hotel manager knew nothing about.An absolutley beautiful and tranquil garden and restaurant. Visited the garden 3 times during our stay for some peace and quiet.The gardens are set around an old residence that resembles an Indian Raj Palace. We ate at the restaurant (The Kaiser Restaurant )which was the best western food we found in Nepal and also went to the Tappas Bar one night for "koala wings" which we thought was quite hilarious being from Australia and never imagining such a thing before!
